content.description: Pit vipers are snakes that have deep sensory openings (pits) between their nostrils and eyes. These pits enable the snakes to sense heat emitted by endotherms, such as mammals, allowing the snakes to find their prey. In an experiment, researchers discovered that nerve cells in the pits transcribe the gene <math alttext="T R P A 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mi>A</mi><mn mathvariant="italic">1</mn></math> <math alttext="400" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>400</mn></math> times more often than do other nerve cells in the snakes. The researchers claim that the <math alttext="T R P A 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mi>A</mi><mn mathvariant="italic">1</mn></math> gene is involved in the snakes’ ability to sense heat.
